Class KernelTransactionImplementation

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.neo4j.kernel.impl.api.KernelTransactionImplementation
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable, ExecutionStatistics, AssertOpen, KernelTransaction, TxStateHolder

extends Object
implements KernelTransaction, TxStateHolder, ExecutionStatistics

      • transactionHeapBytesLimit

        private volatile long transactionHeapBytesLimit

      • terminationReleaseLock

        private final Lock terminationReleaseLock
        Lock prevents transaction markForTermination(Status) transaction termination} from interfering with transaction commit and specifically with release(). Termination can run concurrently with commit and we need to make sure that it terminates the right lock client and the right transaction (with the right reuseCount) because KernelTransactionImplementation instances are pooled.

      • markForTermination

        boolean markForTermination​(long expectedReuseCount,
                           Status reason)

      • markForTermination

        public void markForTermination​(Status reason)
        Marks this transaction for termination, such that it cannot commit successfully and will try to be terminated by having other methods throw a specific termination exception, as to sooner reach the assumed point where KernelTransaction.close() will be invoked.

        This method is guarded by terminationReleaseLock to coordinate concurrent KernelTransaction.close() and release() calls.

        Specified by:
        markForTermination in interface KernelTransaction

      • isSchemaTransaction

        public boolean isSchemaTransaction()
        Specified by:
        isSchemaTransaction in interface KernelTransaction
        Returns:
        whether or not this transaction is a schema transaction. Type of transaction is decided on first write operation, be it data or schema operation.

      • commit

        public long commit()
            throws TransactionFailureException
        Description copied from interface: KernelTransaction
        Commit and any changes introduced as part of this transaction. Any transaction that was not committed will be rolled back when it will be closed. When commit() is completed, all resources are released and no more changes are possible in this transaction.
        Specified by:
        commit in interface KernelTransaction
        Returns:
        id of the committed transaction or KernelTransaction.ROLLBACK_ID if transaction was rolled back or KernelTransaction.READ_ONLY_ID if transaction was read-only.
        Throws:
        TransactionFailureException

        Specified by:

      • failOnNonExplicitRollbackIfNeeded

        private void failOnNonExplicitRollbackIfNeeded()
                                        throws TransactionFailureException
        Throws exception if this transaction was marked as successful but failure flag has also been set to true.

        This could happen when:

        • caller explicitly calls both success() and failure()
        • caller explicitly calls success() but transaction execution fails
        • caller explicitly calls success() but transaction is terminated

        Throws:
        TransactionFailureException - when execution failed
        TransactionTerminatedException - when transaction was terminated

      • commitTransaction

        Specified by:

      • freezeLocks

        public void freezeLocks()
        Description copied from interface: KernelTransaction
        Forbid acquisition and releasing of locks on this transaction. Any call through the kernel API that requires a lock to be acquired or released will throw a FrozenLocksException. Calling `freezeLocks` several times will nest the freezing. A transaction can be opened to new lock interactions again by calling KernelTransaction.thawLocks() once for every freeze.
        Specified by:
        freezeLocks in interface KernelTransaction

      • thawLocks

        public void thawLocks()
               throws LocksNotFrozenException
        Description copied from interface: KernelTransaction
        Allow acquisition and releasing of locks on this transaction. Thaws one nesting of KernelTransaction.freezeLocks(), which restores the Transaction to normal operation if there has been the same number of freeze and thaw calls.
        Specified by:
        thawLocks in interface KernelTransaction
        Throws:
        LocksNotFrozenException - if the locks were not frozen.

      • forceThawLocks

        private void forceThawLocks()

      • releaseStatementResources

        void releaseStatementResources()
        Release resources for the current statement because it's being closed.

      • release

        private void release()
        Release resources held up by this transaction & return it to the transaction pool. This method is guarded by terminationReleaseLock to coordinate concurrent markForTermination(Status) calls.

      • canBeTerminated

        private boolean canBeTerminated()
        Transaction can be terminated only when it is not closed and not already terminated. Otherwise termination does not make sense.

      • isTerminated

        public boolean isTerminated()

        Returns:
        true if transaction was terminated, otherwise false

      • overrideWith

        public KernelTransaction.Revertable overrideWith​(SecurityContext context)
        Description copied from interface: KernelTransaction
        Temporarily override this transaction's SecurityContext. The override should be reverted using the returned KernelTransaction.Revertable.
        Specified by:
        overrideWith in interface KernelTransaction
        Parameters:
        context - the temporary SecurityContext.
        Returns:
        KernelTransaction.Revertable which reverts to the original SecurityContext.

      • dispose

        public void dispose()

      • activeLocks

        public Stream<ActiveLock> activeLocks()
        This method will be invoked by concurrent threads for inspecting the locks held by this transaction.

        The fact that statementLocks is a volatile fields, grants us enough of a read barrier to get a good enough snapshot of the lock state (as long as the underlying methods give us such guarantees).

        Returns:
        the locks held by this transaction.
